module.name: HTML
module.param:
If you set the URLLoader module's "keepURLUpdated" param to "True", two things will happen:
  1. Any time a user changes the selected value of a Pulldown, TextField, Checkbox, SearchBar or TimeRangePicker module, their change will be reflected in the page URL.
  2. After one or more changes, when the user uses the back and forward buttons in your browser, they will take you back and forth between these different states and the UI elements will set themselves accordingly.

It goes without saying that this is a dramatic improvement to the overall usability of any interactive views. If we dont seem as excited about this as we should be, it's because this took a lot of work to pull off. All Sideview apps going forward are going to be leveraging this technology, and it's yet another reason to jump in to Sideview Utils with both feet.

  1. An alternative version of the Splunk Search UI, but with back button support.
  2. one of the testcase views that we use to test the functionality.

module.name: HTML
module.param:
Notes:
  1. If you dont want this behavior, just dont set the 'keepURLUpdated' param because the default value is "False".
  2. Clicks and selections on FlashTimeline, FlashChart and SimpleResultsTable modules are NOT persisted. This may come in a future version but it may not.
  3. Known bug 1: The initial state that the SearchBar and the TimeRangePicker load in, when the URL is completely blank, may not restore correctly when you use the back buton to return to that initial state before URLLoader started modifying the URL. We consider this a minor bug because in cases where the very first URL the user comes in on already has searchBar, earliest and latest set in the querystring args, the bug will not manifest.
  4. Known bug 2: Back and forward may sometimes not restore the 'all time' timerange.
  5. Known bug 3: If you build up a few entries in the document hash by running searches and then you explicitly reload the page, you will only be able to partially restore the previous states before the page was reloaded.
  6. If you see anything that looks like a bug, or just seems weird, PLEASE LET US KNOW. This was a tricky piece of engineering to lay down on top of the Splunk UI and there are probably several bugs still hiding in there.
